newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks seen weak but close to floor.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks seen weak but close to floor.

text.p: Argentine stocks were expected to slip further into negative territory at the opening Thursday but may find support later in the session, dealers said.

"The market is facing a lot of pressure from Congress, which seems in no hurry to pass fiscal reforms. However things are probably not as bleak as they seem," said Norman Trabucco at traders Zaracan. "We should expect a rebound soon."
The blue-chip MerVal index dived more than 5.0 percent between Tuesday and Wednesday, rattled by talk Congress may not pass the fiscal package until early October.

Traders noted any congressional opposition to the reforms drafted by Economy Minister Roque Fernandez would revive old political and economic worries and cast doubts on the new minister's clout vis-a-vis his predecessor, Domingo Cavallo.
But while approval of the tax hikes and other measures was considered essential to plug Argentina's fiscal gap, there was also a sense the government only touched the surface.
"The main problem with the package is it aims to squeeze more money out of the usual taxpayers, and does not battle chronic problems of corruption, evasion and overspending," said Trabucco.
"Perhaps the news that will help the markets snap their losing streak will come from the IMF," he added, referring to ongoing talks with an International Monetary Fund delegation.

Argentina overshot first-half fiscal targets by $1.0 billion and Fernandez has said the yearly deficit could more than double the original $2.5 billion goal agreed with the Fund if Congress does not pass his package.
The visiting IMF team is scheduled to meet Fernandez Friday.
